articles.headline: Fears of European Slowdown Weaken the Euro
articles.snippet: The euro tumbled Friday to near the $1.50 mark — its lowest level against the dollar since February — amid new signs that the European economy was slowing.
articles.abstract: The euro tumbled Friday to near the $1.50 mark — its lowest level against the dollar since February — amid new signs that the European economy was slowing.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  The euro tumbled Friday to near the $1.50 mark  its lowest level against the dollar since February  amid new signs that the European economy was slowing.

articles.headline: Even Small Nest Eggs Need Advice
articles.snippet: The clients most in need of help often get the least access to competent financial advice. But Citi’s global wealth management unit has come up with a way to try to serve this untapped market.
articles.abstract: The clients most in need of help often get the least access to competent financial advice. But Citi’s global wealth management unit has come up with a way to try to serve this untapped market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s the sad truth of the financial advice industry: The clients most in need of unbiased help often get the least access to competent assistance.

articles.headline: Leaks in Patch for Web Security Hole
articles.snippet: A software patch intended to fix a serious flaw in the Internet’s workings appears to have some gaping holes.
articles.abstract: A software patch intended to fix a serious flaw in the Internet’s workings appears to have some gaping holes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Faced with the discovery of a serious flaw in the Internet’s workings, computer network administrators around the world have been rushing to fix their systems with a cobbled-together patch. Now it appears that the patch has some gaping holes.

articles.headline: Mortgage Rates, Down for So Long, Are Creeping Back Up and Crimping Affordability
articles.snippet: If you are a prospective home buyer waiting for the bottom of the housing market, there is another fact you need to take into account: mortgage rates are rising.
articles.abstract: If you are a prospective home buyer waiting for the bottom of the housing market, there is another fact you need to take into account: mortgage rates are rising.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you are a prospective home buyer waiting for the bottom of the housing market, there is another fact you need to take into account: mortgage rates are rising.

articles.headline: Tape Delay by NBC Faces End Run by Online Fans
articles.snippet: NBC’s decision about the Olympics opening ceremonies sent people to their computers to poke holes in a technological wall.
articles.abstract: NBC’s decision about the Olympics opening ceremonies sent people to their computers to poke holes in a technological wall.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC, which owns the exclusive rights to broadcast the Olympics in the United States, spent most of Friday trying to keep it that way.

articles.headline: As Program Moves Poor to Suburbs, Tensions Follow
articles.snippet: Social and racial tensions have followed the resettling of thousands of poor, often African-American residents from the nation’s largest cities to the suburbs.
articles.abstract: Social and racial tensions have followed the resettling of thousands of poor, often African-American residents from the nation’s largest cities to the suburbs.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTIOCH, Calif.  From the tough streets of Oakland, where so many of Alice Payne’s relatives and friends had been shot to death, the newspaper advertisement for a federally assisted rental property in this Northern California suburb was like a bridge across the River Jordan.

articles.headline: Edwards Admits to Affair in 2006
articles.snippet: Former Senator John Edwards said he had “a liaison” with a woman who was not his wife, but he denied that he was the father of her baby.
articles.abstract: Former Senator John Edwards said he had “a liaison” with a woman who was not his wife, but he denied that he was the father of her baby.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former Senator John Edwards of North Carolina said Friday that he had an affair in 2006 with a woman who was not his wife. But he denied that he was the father of her baby, who was born in February, about a month after Mr. Edwards dropped out of the race for president.

articles.headline: Diamonds Are Forever in Botswana
articles.snippet: Botswana’s economic development has been aided by diamonds and by De Beers’s sense of corporate social responsibility.
articles.abstract: Botswana’s economic development has been aided by diamonds and by De Beers’s sense of corporate social responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1967, the year after Botswana gained its independence from Britain, a huge diamond mine was discovered in a remote area called Orapa, about 250 miles from the capital city of Gaborone. The company that found the mine was De Beers, which was then  as it is now  the dominant seller of “rough stones” in the world. Four years and $33 million later, the mine was ready for production.

articles.headline: Calculating Where Home Prices Will Land
articles.snippet: Housing continues to pull down the economy, but some say the pain is ending. Are they right?
articles.abstract: Housing continues to pull down the economy, but some say the pain is ending. Are they right?
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest. No one actually knows when and where the housing market will bottom. Experts have been proclaiming the bottom is now  this very moment  since Alan Greenspan notoriously predicted the worst was over way back in 2006.

articles.headline: Georgia and Russia Nearing All-Out War
articles.snippet: As Russia moved in more forces and continued aerial bombing, it appeared determined to occupy South Ossetia and Abkhazia.
articles.abstract: As Russia moved in more forces and continued aerial bombing, it appeared determined to occupy South Ossetia and Abkhazia.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Anne Barnard, Andrew E. Kramer, and C. J. Chivers and written by Ms. Barnard.

articles.headline: Outside U.S., Credit Cards Tighten Grip
articles.snippet: Credit cards have become commonplace in Turkey, but so has the curse of debt.
articles.abstract: Credit cards have become commonplace in Turkey, but so has the curse of debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL  In Turkey, where borrowing money was until very recently a family affair, being in debt carried a fearful stigma. Some here even likened it to the disgrace that drives people to commit the honor killings that still occur in parts of this society.

articles.headline: Darfur Withers as Sudan Sells Food
articles.snippet: Sudan is capitalizing on high global food prices at a time when millions there barely have enough to eat.
articles.abstract: Sudan is capitalizing on high global food prices at a time when millions there barely have enough to eat.
articles.lead_paragraph: ED DAMER, Sudan  Even as it receives a billion pounds of free food from international donors, Sudan is growing and selling vast quantities of its own crops to other countries, capitalizing on high global food prices at a time when millions of people in its war-riddled region of Darfur barely have enough to eat.

articles.headline: Holy Cash Cow, Batman! Content Is Back
articles.snippet: As Jeff Bewkes whittles away at the Time Warner empire, it’s become clear that the company will have unraveled the two great megamergers that created its current shape.
articles.abstract: As Jeff Bewkes whittles away at the Time Warner empire, it’s become clear that the company will have unraveled the two great megamergers that created its current shape.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON an early Saturday morning about three weeks ago, Barry M. Meyer pulled a sheet of paper from the fax machine in his home office, inhaled deeply and held it up to the light of a nearby window.

articles.headline: Naked Came the Speculators
articles.snippet: As regulators try to get a handle on the runaway freight train known as the credit default swap market, companies that sold default insurance are getting hammered.
articles.abstract: As regulators try to get a handle on the runaway freight train known as the credit default swap market, companies that sold default insurance are getting hammered.
articles.lead_paragraph: REINING in the runaway freight train otherwise known as the credit default swap market is a rising priority for regulators who oversee banks and insurers. It’s a good thing, too, given the secretive nature of the swaps, the losses they are generating at some companies and the size of the market: $62 trillion in default insurance is outstanding, with a fair value of $2 trillion at the end of 2007.

articles.headline: In Loose Style, McCain Leads a Camp Divided
articles.snippet: John McCain has been the overseer of a kingdom with unclear lines of command that keeps aides on edge.
articles.abstract: John McCain has been the overseer of a kingdom with unclear lines of command that keeps aides on edge.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain is so quick to pick up his gold-colored cellphone to solicit advice  from senators, campaign consultants, even the stray former deputy press secretary  that aides, concerned about his tendency to adopt the last opinion he has heard, have tried to cut back on the time he has to make calls.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: An Old Rocker Gets Digital
articles.snippet: Peter Gabriel, the rock musician, has become a powerful player in the emerging online music industry by helping artists find new ways to market their music on the Web.
articles.abstract: Peter Gabriel, the rock musician, has become a powerful player in the emerging online music industry by helping artists find new ways to market their music on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Charles Grimsdale, a British investor, started the Internet music venture OD2 in 1999, he had a hard time persuading large record companies to license their music. But when he approached the rock musician Peter Gabriel about putting his music catalog online, he got a very different response: Mr. Gabriel was not only willing, he also wanted to take a stake in the company.

articles.headline: When Experts Retire, How to Replace Them?
articles.snippet: One executive discusses the acute challenge of replacing employees who are set to retire in the next few years.
articles.abstract: One executive discusses the acute challenge of replacing employees who are set to retire in the next few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: I WORK for the Midwest Independent Transmission System Operator, known as Midwest I.S.O. We oversee the power grid in 15 states and in Manitoba, Canada, for 27 power companies.

articles.headline: Russians Push Past Separatist Area to Assault Central Georgia
articles.snippet: The maneuver suggested that Russia’s aims had gone beyond securing the enclaves of South Ossetia and Abkhazia to weakening the armed forces of Georgia.
articles.abstract: The maneuver suggested that Russia’s aims had gone beyond securing the enclaves of South Ossetia and Abkhazia to weakening the armed forces of Georgia.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Andrew E. Kramer, Anne Barnard and C. J. Chivers, and written by Ms. Barnard.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard, Andrew E. Kramer and C. J. Chivers

articles.headline: All of Us, the Arbiters of News
articles.snippet: In the age of Twitter and YouTube, crowds are driving the media agendas.
articles.abstract: In the age of Twitter and YouTube, crowds are driving the media agendas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early on in any journalist’s career, the young reporter is besieged by advice from all sides. Flacks, sources and run-of-the-mill busybodies will pound on the phone about why the reporter isn’t covering this or that story. And then, a sage editor will appear and counsel the newbie: “We decide what the news is.”

articles.headline: Media Outlets Losing Money From a Lack of Auto Ads
articles.snippet: The flight of advertising dollars to the Internet is one explanation for the pain felt by traditional media. Another culprit that is increasingly to blame is Detroit.
articles.abstract: The flight of advertising dollars to the Internet is one explanation for the pain felt by traditional media. Another culprit that is increasingly to blame is Detroit.
articles.lead_paragraph: The flight of advertising dollars to the Internet is one explanation for the pain felt by traditional media.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Stuart Elliott

articles.headline: Is Google a Media Company?
articles.snippet: Knol, Google’s new site where experts share knowledge on a variety of topics, has rekindled fears among some media companies that Google is edging in on their turf.
articles.abstract: Knol, Google’s new site where experts share knowledge on a variety of topics, has rekindled fears among some media companies that Google is edging in on their turf.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Type “buttermilk pancakes” into Google, and among the top three or four search results you will find a link to a detailed recipe complete with a photo of a scrumptious stack from a site called Knol, which is owned by Google.

articles.headline: Show Skewers Martha Stewart, With Her Blessing
articles.snippet: Can Martha Stewart take a pie in the face -- even one she baked? Fine Living Network, about to unveil a new comedy series -- “Whatever, Martha!” -- is about to find out.
articles.abstract: Can Martha Stewart take a pie in the face -- even one she baked? Fine Living Network, about to unveil a new comedy series -- “Whatever, Martha!” -- is about to find out.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Can Martha Stewart take a pie in the face  even one she baked herself? Fine Living Network is about to find out.

articles.headline: Web Privacy on the Radar in Congress
articles.snippet: As advertisers grow more sophisticated about behavioral targeting, and as online privacy standards vary, regulators and privacy advocates are becoming concerned.
articles.abstract: As advertisers grow more sophisticated about behavioral targeting, and as online privacy standards vary, regulators and privacy advocates are becoming concerned.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here are some things Internet users can discover about Kiyoshi Martinez, a 24-year-old man from Mokena, Ill., from some of his recent posts online. He watched “The Colbert Report” on Tuesday night, he likes the musician Lenlow and he received bottles of olive oil and vinegar for his birthday. Mr. Martinez has Facebook and LinkedIn pages, a Twitter account and a Web site that includes his résumé.

articles.headline: Iraq Private Sector Falters; Rolls of Government Soar
articles.snippet: The number of Iraqi government employees has nearly doubled since 2005, while private enterprise has failed to flourish amid the damaged infrastructure.
articles.abstract: The number of Iraqi government employees has nearly doubled since 2005, while private enterprise has failed to flourish amid the damaged infrastructure.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Hampered by years of violence, a decimated infrastructure, a lack of foreign investors and a flood of imports that undercut local businesses, Iraq’s private sector, particularly its small non-oil economy, has so far failed to flourish as its American patrons had hoped.

articles.headline: On Slog to Safety, Seething at West
articles.snippet: It was the question of the day among exhausted Georgians: Where are the United States and NATO?
articles.abstract: It was the question of the day among exhausted Georgians: Where are the United States and NATO?
articles.lead_paragraph: GORI, Georgia  In retreat, the Georgian soldiers were so tired they could not keep from stumbling. Their arms were loaded with rucksacks and ammunition boxes; they had dark circles under their eyes. Officers ran up and down the line, barking for them to go faster.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Ellen Barry
